body.p: You will not expect us of course in this weather my dearest friend, but cannot suffer the servant to go into Reading without aprising you of our regret at being disappointed of our visit Papa particularly laments not being able to meet William Hayward, but the roads are in such plight & our cavalry so exceedingly inefficient that to the Gig & great coach, through the mire would be impossible to say nothing of the live (or dead) weight which the aforesaid great coach would enclose. You must write to me Saturday my own dear Mary, & give me the good news of the dear Papa. I hope William will take great care of him at Winchester. I wish he was not going. You must likewise give me good tidings of poor Wilson-how sorry we all were for his accident-but dogs will fight-even my exemplary dog Mossy pretty nearly killed one of Mrs. Pile's at Overton. When such a Sir Charles Grandison--sort of dog as Mossy does such things what can be expected of the less educated race! Bye the bye its great good luck that Papa did not harm him.

I have just heard from Miss James who delivers her most particular love to you all, Papa & Aunt Mary included. Some of this letter won't make you laugh. Do come &see it, &see me, &the primroses. Do. Poor Dr. Valpyis very ill we are sending to enquire after him. Good bye, my dear loves. Ever yours
